results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about Polish translations of "Robinson Crusoe" and their publication history in the 19th and 20th centuries:

## Polish Translations of "Robinson Crusoe" - Historical Overview

The only complete Polish translation of the novel is the translation of Volume I done by Józef Birkenmajer, initially published in 1949 under the title "Robinson Kruzoe," and in later editions as "Przypadki Robinsona Kruzoe" (Volume I), along with a translation of Volume II by an anonymous translator from the 19th century. The entire novel, in both translations, was published several times by PIW publishing house (Volume II edited by Grzegorz Sinko).

## Recent Complete Edition (2025)

In 2025, the complete work was also published by Ossolineum publishing house in the "Biblioteka Narodowa" series, and this edition also contains a collection of essays titled "Serious Reflections of Robinson Crusoe".(no content)In the Biblioteka Narodowa series, Ossolineum published the first complete (3-volume) edition in Polish of the famous novel "Robinson Crusoe" by Daniel Defoe.(no content)The author of the scholarly edition is Dr. hab. Jakub Lipski, professor at the Department of English-Language Literatures at the Faculty of Literary Studies at UKW.

## Historical Context

Polish readers had to wait over 300 years for the first complete edition of "Robinson Crusoe" in Polish.(no content)The fact that Defoe's novel consists of three volumes is not and never has been widely known.(no content)The new Ossolineum edition is one of the few complete scholarly works in the world, taking into account both the coherence of the three components of the trilogy and the tensions revealed between them.

## Publishing Houses and Editions

The search results indicate that major Polish publishers involved in publishing "Robinson Crusoe" translations include:
- **PIW** (Państwowy Instytut Wydawniczy) - published multiple editions
- **Ossolineum** - published the recent complete 2025 edition in the "Biblioteka Narodowa" series
- Various other publishers have produced adaptations and incomplete versions over the years

The historical significance lies in the fact that for over three centuries, Polish readers only had access to incomplete versions or adaptations of Defoe's work, with the anonymous 19th-century translation of Volume II being one of the few historical Polish translations available until the modern complete edition.
